bestBHT.bht: The reference to the bush pertains to a section in the book of Moses, specifically Exodus 3:2-6. This portion is known as the place concerning the bush. In this narrative, God proclaims, I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, which provides evidence for the resurrection of the dead. The practice of identifying scripture sections by significant elements, such as the bush, was customary among the Jews.

Henry Alford: The words may in the original mean either, ‘in the chapter containing the history of God appearing in the Bush,’ or, ‘when he was at the Bush.’
The former is the more probable, on account of the construction of the verse in our text.
In Luke, if we had his account alone, the other rendering might be admissible, ‘Moses testified, at the Bush:' but this will not answer in our text.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: And as touching the dead, that they rise: have ye not read in the book of Moses...how in the bush God spake unto him."
Either 'at the bush,' as the same expression is rendered in Luke 20:37, that is, when he was there; or 'in the [section of his history regarding the] bush.'
Saying, I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob?
Marvin Vincent: In the bush [επι του βατου], refers to a particular section in the Pentateuch, Exodus 3:2-6."
The Jews were accustomed to designate portions of scripture by the most noteworthy thing contained in them.
The article refers to it as something familiar.
Archibald T. Robertson: In the place concerning the Bush (επ του βατου).
Βατος is masculine here, feminine in Luke 20:37.
The reference is to Exodus 3:3-6 (in the book of Moses, εν τη βιβλω).
John Gill: For the proof of the doctrine of the resurrection of the dead, have ye not read in the book of Moses...
The book of Exodus is particularly intended; for the passage referred to is in Exodus 3:6...
Saying, I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob?

bhtAttempts.bht: In Mark 12:26, the reference to the bush is a specific section in the Pentateuch (Exodus 3:2-6). The verse can be translated as either in the chapter containing the history of God appearing in the Bush or when he was at the Bush. The Jews often designated scripture portions by the most noteworthy thing contained in them, which is why it is referred to as the place concerning the Bush. In Exodus 3:6, God declares, I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, demonstrating the truth of the resurrection of the dead.

The reference to the bush in Mark 12:26 corresponds to a specific section in Exodus where God appeared. This section is referred to as the place concerning the Bush. In this passage, God declares, I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, providing evidence for the resurrection of the dead. The Jews had a practice of identifying scripture portions by notable elements within them.

The reference to the bush in the mentioned verse corresponds to a particular section in the Pentateuch, specifically Exodus 3:2-6 in the book of Moses. This section is referred to as the place concerning the bush. God's declaration, I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, serves as evidence for the resurrection of the dead. The Jews had a tradition of identifying scripture portions by significant elements within them, which explains the designation of the bush.

The reference to the bush pertains to a section in the book of Moses, specifically Exodus 3:2-6. This portion is known as the place concerning the bush. In this narrative, God proclaims, I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, which provides evidence for the resurrection of the dead. The practice of identifying scripture sections by significant elements, such as the bush, was customary among the Jews.

The reference to the bush in Mark 12:26 is connected to a specific section in the Pentateuch found in Exodus 3:2-6, known as the place concerning the bush. This passage showcases God's declaration, I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, which presents compelling evidence for the resurrection of the dead. It was customary for the Jews to use significant elements to denote sections of scripture, such as the bush in this instance.
